data.title: 34 Epic Road Trip Movies to Watch
data.meta_description: Into the Wild • Green Book • Joy Ride • Nomadland • Little Miss Sunshine • Drive My Car • Thelma and Louise • Queen and Slim • The Highwaymen • Due Date • End of the Road • Almost Famous • Magic Mike XXL
data.text:
A road trip often serves a bildungsroman, a coming-of-age story in which the hero changes and grows over the course of the story. It’s a standard film plot employed by screenwriters, yet there is so much variety in this genre.

Romance, drama, comedy, thriller. Spontaneous trips filled with adventure or planned vacations gone awry. By bus, by car, by motorcycle, or even by lawnmower. Strippers, musicians, families. For revenge or for redemption. Sometimes they’re serious, but they can also be good fun.

So grab your popcorn and buckle up! Let these diverse movies transport you somewhere new and inspire you to get out on the road to self-discovery.

Into the Wild

Into the Wild (2007) is an introspective biographical drama that tells the compelling true story of a young man, Chris McCandless, who rejects his privileged upbringing to embark on a cross-country road trip in search of meaning and self-discovery. Leaving his comfortable life behind, Chris (played by Emile Hirsch) ventures into the unforgiving wilderness of Alaska, where he must confront the harsh realities and devastating consequences of his solitary existence. Like the Jon Krakauer book it’s adapted from, enjoy emotional encounters with fellow travellers and profound moments of self-reflection, plus the beautiful scenery of the north.

Green Book

Green Book (2018) deservedly won Best Picture at the 2019 Academy Awards. Set in the 1960s, the film is a historical drama about travel in the racially-divided American South. It tells a fictionalized account of a real road trip taken by Dr. Don Shirley (played by Mahershala Ali), a world-class African-American pianist, and his hired driver, Italian-American bouncer from the Bronx Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen). As they set out on a concert tour, they rely on the Green Book, a guide for Black travellers, to find safe accommodations. Despite their differences and encountering the harsh realities of racism, the pair challenge their preconceptions and prejudices and form an unexpected bond.

Joy Ride

In the movie Joy Ride (2001), three college friends set out on a road trip that quickly takes a sinister turn. Lewis, Fuller, and Venna (played by Paul Walker, Steve Zahn, and Leelee Sobieski, respectively) discover a CB radio and decide to have some fun by pretending to be a woman named Candy Cane. However, their prank turns deadly when they unknowingly provoke a trucker named Rusty Nail, who becomes obsessed with seeking revenge. As Rusty Nail terrorizes and hunts them down, the friends find themselves in a race against time to outsmart their relentless pursuer and survive the nightmarish journey they didn’t expect.

Nomadland

Nomadland (2020) is an Oscar-winning film that explores the life of Fern, a woman in her sixties who loses her job and embarks on a transformative journey across the American West in her van. Embracing the nomadic lifestyle and encountering a diverse group of fellow wanderers, Fern (played by Frances McDormand) discovers the beauty of living in the moment and finds solace in the vast landscapes that effortlessly capture the essence of freedom and human connection. Through both the challenges and the joys she encounters on her unconventional path, Fern learns to redefine her relationship with society, material possessions, and ultimately, with herself.

Little Miss Sunshine

In the heartwarming and goofy film Little Miss Sunshine (2006), the eccentric Hoover family goes on a road trip from Albuquerque to California, with one goal in mind: to support their youngest child, Olive, as she competes in a beauty pageant. However, each family member carries their own emotional baggage and faces personal challenges. Packed with quirky characters, unexpected twists, and a touching exploration of acceptance and individuality, Little Miss Sunshine is a delightful journey. Remember: A real loser is somebody who is so afraid of not winning they don't even try.

Drive My Car

In the critically acclaimed film Drive My Car (2021), directed by Ryusuke Hamaguchi, renowned theater director Yusuke Kafuku mourns the loss of his wife while grappling with unresolved conflicts in their relationship. As part of his healing process, Yusuke agrees to direct a stage adaptation of Anton Chekhov's play Uncle Vanya. The festival requires that he be chauffeured in his own car for insurance reasons, so he hires Misaki to take him around town. As they spend more time together on the road, Yusuke slowly opens up about his past and the complexities of his relationships. The movie navigates the intricacies of love, grief, and forgiveness against the backdrop of the beautiful Japanese countryside.

Thelma and Louise

In the unforgettable classic film Thelma and Louise (1991), directed by Ridley Scott, the two best friends embark on a transformative journey filled with adventure, self-discovery—and unexpected consequences. The duo sets off on a weekend road trip together, but their little excursion takes a dramatic turn when an unsettling incident forces them to flee from the law. Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon are exceptional, and the movie has become a landmark feminist film.

Queen and Slim

In the darkly romantic movie Queen and Slim (2019), a young couple on their first date unintentionally kill a police officer in self-defence during a routine traffic stop. Faced with the harsh reality of their actions and aware of the systemic injustice they might face, they make a fateful decision to go on the run. As their journey unfolds, they become modern-day folk heroes and symbols of resistance against oppression. Queen and Slim, starring Daniel Kaluuya and Jodie Turner-Smith, explores the complex theme of racial injustice, and when I saw this movie in a sold-out cinema in Paris, it received a standing ovation.

The Highwaymen

The Highwaymen (2019) is a gripping dramatic film. Set in the 1930s, it tells the untold story of two former Texas Rangers, Frank Hamer (played by Kevin Costner) and Maney Gault (Woody Harrelson), who come out of retirement to hunt down and capture the infamous outlaws, Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow. As they embark on this dangerous pursuit, they face numerous obstacles, the biggest being the media glorifying the criminals as heroes. Even though it’s based on a true story and we know the ending, how they get there is still interesting.

Due Date

In the hilarious comedy film Due Date (2010), directed by Todd Phillips, Peter Highman (played by Robert Downey Jr.) is a stressed expectant father who finds himself on an unpredictable cross-country road trip with an eccentric yet well-meaning aspiring actor, Ethan Tremblay (Zach Galifianakis). Peter's misadventure begins when he is placed on the no-fly list, leaving him with no alternative but to share a car with Ethan in order to reach home before his wife's due date. As the mismatched duo deals with car accidents and confrontations with law enforcement, their journey becomes a test of both patience and friendship.

End of the Road

In the crime thriller End of the Road (2022), Brenda Freeman (played by Queen Latifah) and her children, accompanied by her brother (Ludacris), set out on a life-changing move across the country after the loss of her husband. On the road, they stumble upon a dangerous secret involving stolen cash from a ruthless cartel. With their lives in jeopardy and loved ones held hostage, Brenda must navigate a treacherous path filled with unexpected alliances and intense confrontations. The Freemans discover their own strength and resilience along the way, ultimately finding hope and a chance for a fresh start.

Almost Famous

A coming-of-age film set in the early 1970s, Almost Famous (2000) follows the story of a talented and ambitious teenage journalist, William Miller. When William gets the chance to travel with an up-and-coming rock band, Stillwater, for a magazine assignment, he finds himself thrown into the exhilarating world of sex, drugs, and rock and roll. As he navigates the chaotic and glamorous music industry, William experiences a collision of love, friendship, and disillusionment, ultimately discovering his own identity and voice in the process.

Easy Rider

In Magic Mike XXL (2015), Mike, three years after retiring from the stripping world, is enticed to hit the road with his former crew for one last thrilling performance at the legendary Stripper Convention in Myrtle Beach. Determined to go out with a bang, they create impressive new dance routines and indulge in wild parties on their way there—and Mike (played by Channing Tatum) rediscovers his passion for stripping while finding fresh perspectives on life, friendship, and self-acceptance. This might be the best movie in the Magic Mike trilogy: it’s funnier, has a stronger plot, and—the real reason we watch these movies—better dancing.

The Motorcycle Diaries

The Motorcycle Diaries (2004) is a dramatized account of Ernesto "Che" Guevara's transformative motorcycle trip across South America as a young medical student. On the road with his friend Alberto Granado, this inspiring tale chronicles their eye-opening encounters with the diverse inhabitants of the continent and the harsh realities that the impoverished face. The trip gradually shapes their perspectives and political ideologies, ultimately propelling them towards their respective destinies. The Motorcycle Diaries, starring Gael García Bernal and Rodrigo de la Serna, is an exploration of self-discovery within these two young adventurers.

One Week

One Week (2008) is a heartwarming Canadian film that follows the journey of Ben (played by Canadian actor Joshua Jackson), a young man who is diagnosed with a terminal illness. Faced with the fragility of life and the uncertainty of the future, Ben embarks on a spontaneous road trip across Canada on his motorcycle. Along the way, he encounters various people and places that challenge his perspectives and evoke deep introspection. Through this transformative odyssey, Ben seeks to find meaning, embrace the fleeting beauty of existence, and ultimately discover his own path in the limited time he has left.

Plan B

Plan B (2021) is a hilarious and heartfelt comedy that follows high school friends Lupe and Sunny on a wild adventure after a wild party. In search of a Plan B pill, the two head out to the local pharmacy, but are denied, so they set off for Planned Parenthood. As they encounter a series of outrageous obstacles, Lupe (played by Victoria Moroles) and Sunny (Kuhoo Verma) learn invaluable lessons about friendship and the power of embracing their true selves. With a perfect blend of laughter and heart, Plan B delivers a refreshing and empowering take on teenage life.

Dumb and Dumber

In the hilarious comedy film Dumb and Dumber (1994), best friends Lloyd and Harry (played by Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels, respectively) go on an outrageous cross-country adventure after a case of mistaken identity and a stolen briefcase filled with money. Unaware of the true danger they face, the duo's dim-witted antics not only test their friendship but also turn their seemingly simple mission into a whirlwind of mishaps, odd encounters, and absurd situations. Road trip navigators everywhere: “According to the map, we've only gone about 4 inches!”

On the Road

On the Road (2012) is an adventurous drama that follows the journey of Sal Paradise, a young writer in the late 1940s. After the death of his father and the end of a romantic relationship, Sal goes on a soul-searching road trip across America with his free-spirited friend, Dean Moriarty. Together, they drive into a counterculture world of poetry, jazz, and sex. As they traverse the country together, exploring the boundaries of love, friendship, and freedom, their experiences shape their understanding of themselves and the world around them. The movie is adapted from the classic Beat Generation novel by Jack Kerouac.

RV

In the funny family film RV (2006), a workaholic father named Bob Munro (played by Robin Williams) decides to take his dysfunctional family on a much-needed vacation to the Rocky Mountains in a rented RV. (The movie was filmed in British Columbia and Alberta.) However, their dream of a relaxing trip quickly becomes a wild adventure filled with hilarious mishaps and unexpected detours. As Bob tries to keep up the appearance of the perfect family vacation, they encounter a series of comical and chaotic situations that ultimately bring them closer together.

Get on the Bus

In Get on the Bus (1996), directed by Spike Lee, a diverse group of African-American men embarks on a journey from Los Angeles to Washington, D.C. to participate in the Million Man March in 1995. As they travel on an old graffiti-covered bus, tensions arise among individuals from different backgrounds, including a father hoping to bond with his estranged son, a gay couple seeking acceptance, and a former gang member trying to overcome his past. Throughout the cross-country trip, the passengers engage in passionate discussions and heated debates on issues like racism, sexism, homophobia, and identity. With each passing mile, these confrontations cause them to reflect on the impact the march will have on their lives and the African-American community as a whole.

The Straight Story

The tearjerker The Straight Story (1999) is based on a true story. Alvin Straight, an elderly and determined man, embarks on a remarkable journey to reconcile with his estranged brother, Lyle. Faced with limited mobility due to his age and the lack of a driver’s license, Alvin decides to travel hundreds of miles on a lawnmower to reach Lyle's home. Throughout his arduous odyssey, Alvin shares his life experiences and imparts wisdom on those he encounters, showcasing the power of forgiveness, family bonds, and the resilience of the human spirit. With breathtaking landscapes and genuine emotions, The Straight Story, directed by David Lynch, captures a simple yet extraordinary journey of redemption and reconciliation.

Death Proof

In the critically acclaimed film Y Tu Mamá También (2001), two teenage best friends, Tenoch and Julio, embark on a transformative road trip with an older woman—she’s in her twenties—named Luisa. As the trio sets off on a journey to a fictitious secluded beach, they navigate the complexities of their friendship and relationships. Secrets are revealed, leading to unexpected emotions and consequences. Amidst the picturesque landscapes, the characters are confronted with love and loss and the harsh realities of adulthood. The film set a record for the highest box office opening in Mexican cinema at the time.

Natural Born Killers

Natural Born Killers (1994) is an intense and controversial film that follows the chaotic and twisted journey of Mickey and Mallory Knox, a couple who go on a killing spree across the American Southwest. Mickey (played by Woody Harrelson) and Mallory (Juliette Lewis) gain publicity as they leave a trail of bloody violence. As they evade capture, their brutal actions propel them into the realm of celebrity, much like the story of Bonnie and Clyde.

We’re the Millers

We're the Millers (2013) is a hilarious comedy that follows a small-time drug dealer named David Clark (played by Jason Sudeikis) who, after being robbed of his stash and money, finds himself indebted to his supplier. In order to repay his debt and avoid danger, he concocts a plan to smuggle a huge shipment of marijuana across the Mexican border. To avoid suspicion, he recruits a gang of misfits—a sassy stripper, a nerdy teenager, and a runaway girl—to pose as his fake family on a vacation to Mexico. As they continue on this wild and outrageous adventure, they face numerous hilarious obstacles, all while trying to keep their true identities secret and complete the mission.

Away We Go

Away We Go (2009) is a heartwarming film directed by Sam Mendes. The story follows a young couple, Burt and Verona, played by John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph, as they go on a journey across the United States to find the perfect place to call home before the arrival of their first child. Along the way, they encounter a cast of quirky characters, each with different takes on modern life and parenthood. With its charming mix of humour and emotional depth, Away We Go explores the move from families we come from to families we make.

Kings of the Road

In the movie Kings of the Road (1976), two men embark on a transformative journey as they traverse the length of Germany in a van. Bruno, a film projector repairman, meets Robert, who is struggling through a painful breakup. As they drive across picturesque landscapes and encounter eccentric characters, through introspective conversations and moments of silence, they gradually forge a friendship. The black-and-white film also reflects on the changing world of cinema.

My Own Private Idaho

My Own Private Idaho (1991) is a drama that follows two young hustlers, Mike and Scott, played by River Phoenix and Keanu Reeves respectively, as they traverse the highways from Portland to Idaho in search of Mike’s birth family. The arthouse film, directed by Gus Van Sant, follows an unconventional narrative structure as it explores themes of love, identity, and belonging. It is considered to be a landmark queer film.

Crossroads

In the movie Crossroads (2002), three childhood friends embark on a road trip across the United States in search of their pasts and their futures. Mimi, who is five months pregnant, is going to Los Angeles to audition for a record company. Kit is going to see her fiancé, a student at UCLA. Lucy is going to find her mother in Arizona. As they navigate through their fears and desires, the trio discovers the transformative power of friendship, love, and pursuit of dreams. Crossroads was written by Shonda Rimes and stars Britney Spears, so you know it’s good.

What’s your favourite road trip movie? What others movies should I add to this list? Let me know in the comments below!

Thank you for showing your support through likes, comments, and social shares! If you really enjoyed this post and would like to further support my work, you can Buy Me a Drink. Cheers!
